comments:
Following exception appears while loading "platform:/plugin/org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.notation/model/notation.ecore" model into ResourceSet of TransactionalEditingDomain created by org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.core.GMFEditingDomainFactory (you have to have GMF 2.0 installed in your development platform to be able to reproduce this problem).

Investigations: 
- same model could be correctly loaded using URI created by calling URI.createURI("http://www.eclipse.org/gmf/runtime/1.0.0/notation")
- same model could be correctly loaded into the EditingDomain created by org.eclipse.emf.workspace.WorkspaceEditingDomainFactory
- exception thrown while proxy resolving, this process will be initiated by CrossReferenceAdapter attached to the ResourceSet of GMFEditingDomainFactory

Looks like TransactionChangeRecorder should be corrected to not throw this exception.

Created an attachment (id=72976)
UnitTest producing exception attached.

This looks like the mutually-derived features

   EClass::eSuperTypes
   EClass::eGenericSuperTypes

are firing notifications when one of these features is read and triggers the side-effect of updating the other to match.

In resolving the eSuperTypes proxy, the delegating list sets the resolved EClass as the eGenericSuperType's eClassifier reference.  This side-effect should not send notifications:  if the value of the derived feature has never been accessed (which is why it needs to be set at this time) then a notification is meaningless; the value is not actually *changing* because it was implicitly set.  Or, since this is triggered by proxy resolution, the eGenericSuperType change should be made to look like a proxy resolution, also?

I don't see that the TransactionChangeRecorder can do anything about this:  how is it to know which Notifications it should ignore?  The EClass/EGenericType should not be sending this notification or, at least, the notification should be "isTouch" to indicate that there is no semantic change.  That would resolve the problem (the recorder allows touches to pass).

Created an attachment (id=73050)
Changes that avoid setting the classifier if it's just setting a resolved proxy.

Christian, does this look like a good/general solution?

Thanks for looking at this so quickly, Ed!  That does look like a nice, simple solution.  I'll try it with Alex's unit test to take it for a spin.

Maged, perhaps you can try this patch in your scenario, too?

Ed, your patch works great with Alex's test case.  Are there any other ETypedElements besides the EOperation that need similar treatment?

I'll take your patch to mean that you are volunteering to resolve this in the EMF Core component  :-)
Fixed the version (was indicating 3.0, but this problem was found in 2.3).

Created an attachment (id=73433)
A slightly improved patch

I think this is slightly better, because this ensures that the generic type's eRawType is resolved so that we don't resolve it repeatedly.  The JUnit still passes with this...

And to answer Christian's other question, these two lists are the only places this issue arises
Thanks for the clarification, Ed.  And the update looks good to me.
The changes are committed to CVS.

traces.message: Cannot modify resource set without a write transaction
